Mattias, you're pretty spot on with your characterization of method
1a.  Ju=
st to be clear though, the actual r(x) function tells the CPPN
where it is =
within an agent, while it is the actual x value that
allows for role differ=
entiation. 

As for method 1b, I actually tired it while doing preliminary
=
experiments for the paper.  The results were not quite as good as the
r(x) =
method, which is why we chose to pursue r(x).  The reason for
difference is=
 that in the r(x) method, the x means both position
within the team and pos=
ition within the world.  HyperNEAT can exploit
this by relating agent posit=
ion in the team to agent position in the
world.  For example agents on the =
left need to turn right to reach the
center, and vice versa.  Using method =
1b decouples the idea of team
position and world position, so it is more di=
fficult, but not
impossible, for HyperNEAT to make these kind of discoverie=
s.

I am curious about method 2, it does seem a bit like "naming" the
agent=
s which has shown to be useful in multiagent scenarios.  It is a
bit more t=
han that as the names have real meanings and are not
arbitrarily assigned. =
  I would imagine, for HyperNEAT at least, that
it would be more difficult =
to find global patterns across agents with
method 2, since the CPPN does no=
t have access to that geometric
information.

David






--- In neat@yahoo=
groups.com, "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> It's my u=
nderstanding that the r(x) method (call it method 1a) is
used to
> provide =
the genotype->phenotype conversion with the information required
> to produ=
ce different phenotypes for different starting positions, in
> effect, allo=
wing the HyperNEAT framework to create different phenotypes
> for different=
 roles. This could alternatively have been done by
inputing a
> fifth posot=
ion input node (making the five x1,y1,x2,y2 and Position,
call
> it method =
1b), which would also have allowed the genotype->phenotype
> conversion to =
implement different phenotypes for different roles. 
> 
> My suggestion was=
 simpler still, to implement the same phenotype for
each
> position, but ad=
ding an input node (at the phenotype) specifying
position
> (call it method=
 2). This input could be used to inhibit or excite the
> functioning of nod=
es within the phenotype, depending on position. This
> would also allow rol=
es to evolve, but using a different method.
> 
> For a comprehensive invest=
igation, which might be well beyond the
scope of
> the research - the paper=
 did demonstrate a very successfull test, I'd
> personally like to see all =
three methods implemented. 1a and 1b are very
> similar in reality and geno=
type->phenotype conversion has all the
> information required to switch bet=
ween 1a and 1b internally, though
> supplying the information explicitly as=
 per 1b _might_ be more powerful
> for evolving. 
> 
> with regards,
> matt=
ias
>
